channel.title: [Java] Too much code

item.title: [Java] Too much code
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

Moparisthebest:

That’s right now. Technically you don’t need the final break;, since it’s at the end anyway, but it’s a good idea to leave it since you might go back and add more later and forget about it!

I find that default: is a good way to end switch statements. No break needed, and I have a tendency to never put cases under after default

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Too much code
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Contract.java

/**
 *
 * @author Zyle Moore
 */
public interface Contract {
	public String getContractor();
	public Stone getStone();
	public int getAmount();
	public int getPrice();
}

Stone.java

[code=Java]
/**
*

  • @author Zyle Moore
    */
    public enum Stone {
    COAL(0, 50),
    IRON(1, 100),
    GOLD(2, 200),
    DIAMOND(3, 500);

    private int id;
    private int price;

    private Stone(int id, int price) {
    this.id = id;
    this.price = price;
    }

    public int getId() {
    return id;
    }

    public int getPrice() {
    return price;
    }
    }[/code]

Usage:

Contract contract = new Contract() {
	public String getContractor() {
		return "Stone Heroes";
	}

	public Stone getStone() {
		return Stone.COAL;
	}

	public int getAmount() {
		return 5;
	}

	public int getPrice() {
		(getStone().getPrice() * getAmount()) + 50;
	}
};

Read full topic

item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

I already have saving and loading done. The game saves the inventory, gold, and all the information for the contract. Then it can load it back in later. I didn’t get to it in my book, but I looked it up on a tutorial.

item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres

@Cres wrote:

read on in your book until you get to the part of writing / reading data from another .txt file , a perfect example of this is how RSPServers load their doors , new NPC’s , item stats and prices , etc…

item.title: [Java] Too much code
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

Alright, This is my new code. Much better than before considering it has more features and a lot less code.

[code]import java.util.*;

//ContractSystem Class
public class ContractSystem {

//Make objects out of the necessary classes
mainMenu menu = new mainMenu();
userInput input = new userInput();

//Declare variables
ArrayList<String> companyNames = new ArrayList<String>();
ArrayList<String> ores = new ArrayList<String>();

//addCompanies method
public void addCompanys () {

	//Add company names
	companyNames.add("World Fallout Co. ");
	companyNames.add("Black Fallout Co. ");
	companyNames.add("Break Zombie Co.  ");
	companyNames.add("Stone Zombie Co.  ");
	companyNames.add("Stone Heroes Co.  ");
	companyNames.add("Ghost Method Co.  ");

}

//ores Method
public void ores() {

	//Add ores to the ores array list
	ores.add("Stone.   ");
	ores.add("Coal.    ");
	ores.add("Iron.    ");
	ores.add("Gold.    ");
	ores.add("Diamond. ");

}

//Contract method
public void contracts () {

	//Declare and initialize variables
	int randomCompany = (int) (Math.random() * companyNames.size());
	int randomOreCount = (int) (Math.random() * 9) + 1;
	int randomOre = (int) (Math.random() * ores.size());
	int price1 = 0;
	int price2 = 0;
	int price3 = 0;
	int price4 = 0;
	
	//Apply fixed randomized values for use for a random ore
	int Ore1 = randomOre;
	randomOre = (int) (Math.random() * ores.size());
	int Ore2 = randomOre;
	randomOre = (int) (Math.random() * ores.size());
	int Ore3 = randomOre;
	randomOre = (int) (Math.random() * ores.size());
	int Ore4 = randomOre;
	
	//Apply fixed randomized values for use for a random company
	int Company1 = randomCompany;
	randomCompany = (int) (Math.random() * companyNames.size());
	int Company2 = randomCompany;
	randomCompany = (int) (Math.random() * companyNames.size());
	int Company3 = randomCompany;
	randomCompany = (int) (Math.random() * companyNames.size());
	int Company4 = randomCompany;
	
	//Apply fixed randomized values for use for random number of ores
	int numberOfOres1 = randomOreCount;
	randomOreCount = (int) (Math.random() * 9) + 1;
	int numberOfOres2 = randomOreCount;
	randomOreCount = (int) (Math.random() * 9) + 1;
	int numberOfOres3 = randomOreCount;
	randomOreCount = (int) (Math.random() * 9) + 1;
	int numberOfOres4 = randomOreCount;
	
	int STONE_BASE_PRICE = 10;
	int COAL_BASE_PRICE = 50;
	int IRON_BASE_PRICE = 75;
	int GOLD_BASE_PRICE = 300;
	int DIAMOND_BASE_PRICE = 500;
	int CONTRACT_BONUS = 50;
	
	//If the player doesn't have a contract
	if (Player.hasContract == false) {
	
		//Set the price of the contract based on the ore base price, number of ores and the contract bonus
		if (ores.get(Ore1).equals("Stone.   ")) {
		
			price1 = (STONE_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres1) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore1).equals("Coal.    ")) {
		
			price1 = (COAL_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres1) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore1).equals("Iron.    ")) {
		
			price1 = (IRON_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres1) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore1).equals("Gold.    ")) {
			
			price1 = (GOLD_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres1) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
			
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore1).equals("Diamond. ")) {
		
			price1 = (DIAMOND_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres1) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		//Set the string job1 to print out all of the information gathered for the first contract
		String job1 = "| " + companyNames.get(Company1) + "| Mine " + numberOfOres1 + " " + ores.get(Ore1) + "| " + price1 + "\t Gold Coins |";
		
		//Print out the top of the menu and the first contract
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.println("-------------------------------------------------------------");
		System.out.println("| Company:          | Decription:     | Price:              |");
		System.out.println("|-----------------------------------------------------------|");
		System.out.println(job1);
		
		//Set the price of the contract based on the ore base price, number of ores and the contract bonus
		if (ores.get(Ore2).equals("Stone.   ")) {

			price2 = (STONE_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres2) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore2).equals("Coal.    ")) {
		
			price2 = (COAL_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres2) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore2).equals("Iron.    ")) {
		
			price2 = (IRON_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres2) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore2).equals("Gold.    ")) {
			
			price2 = (GOLD_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres2) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
			
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore2).equals("Diamond. ")) {
		
			price2 = (DIAMOND_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres2) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		//Set the string job2 to print out all of the information gathered for the second contract
		String job2 = "| " + companyNames.get(Company2) + "| Mine " + numberOfOres2 + " " + ores.get(Ore2) + "| " + price2 + "\t Gold Coins |";
		
		//Print out the second contract
		System.out.println(job2);
		
		//Set the price of the contract based on the ore base price, number of ores and the contract bonus
		if (ores.get(Ore3).equals("Stone.   ")) {
		
			price3 = (STONE_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres3) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore3).equals("Coal.    ")) {
			
			price3 = (COAL_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres3) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore3).equals("Iron.    ")) {
		
			price3 = (IRON_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres3) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
			
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore3).equals("Gold.    ")) {
			
			price3 = (GOLD_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres3) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
			
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore3).equals("Diamond. ")) {
		
			price3 = (DIAMOND_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres3) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		//Set the string job3 to print out all of the information gathered for the third contract
		String job3 = "| " + companyNames.get(Company3) + "| Mine " + numberOfOres3 + " " + ores.get(Ore3) + "| " + price3 + "\t Gold Coins |";
		
		//Print out the third contract
		System.out.println(job3);
		
		//Set the price of the contract based on the ore base price, number of ores and the contract bonus
		if (ores.get(Ore4).equals("Stone.   ")) {
		
			price4 = (STONE_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres4) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore4).equals("Coal.    ")) {
		
			price4 = (IRON_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres4) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore4).equals("Iron.    ")) {
		
			price4 = (IRON_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres4) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
			
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore4).equals("Gold.    ")) {
			
			price4 = (GOLD_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres4) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
			
		}
		
		if (ores.get(Ore4).equals("Diamond. ")) {
		
			price4 = (DIAMOND_BASE_PRICE * numberOfOres4) + CONTRACT_BONUS;
		
		}
		
		//Set the string job4 to print out all of the information gathered for the fourth contract
		String job4 = "| " + companyNames.get(Company4) + "| Mine " + numberOfOres4 + " " + ores.get(Ore4) + "| " + price4 + "\t Gold Coins |";
		
		//Print out the fourth countract and the end line of the menu
		System.out.println(job4);
		System.out.println("-------------------------------------------------------------");
		System.out.println("");
		
		//Get user input for the contract they choose
		input.getUserInput("What contract will you accept? (1, 2, 3, 4)");
		
		//If they choose the first contract
		if (input.input.equals("1")) {
		
			//set Player boolean to true
			Player.hasContract = true;

			//Print out the contract again
			System.out.println("");
			System.out.println("You chose contract 1.");
			System.out.println("");
			System.out.println("From:  " + companyNames.get(Company1));
			System.out.println("Job:   Mine " + numberOfOres1 + " " + ores.get(Ore1));
			System.out.println("Price: " + price1 + " Gold Coins");
			System.out.println("");
			
			//set Player values for keeping the contract constant
			Player.currentCompany = companyNames.get(Company1);
			Player.currentOreCount = numberOfOres1;
			Player.currentOre = ores.get(Ore1);
			Player.currentPrice = price1;
			
			//start the main menu
			menu.start();
		
		}
		
		//If they choose the second contract
		if (input.input.equals("2")) {
			
			//set Player boolean to true
			Player.hasContract = true;
			
			//Print out the contract again
			System.out.println("");
			System.out.println("You chose contract 2.");
			System.out.println("");
			System.out.println("From:  " + companyNames.get(Company2));
			System.out.println("Job:   Mine " + numberOfOres2 + " " + ores.get(Ore2));
			System.out.println("Price: " + price2 + " Gold Coins");
			System.out.println("");
			
			//set Player values for keeping the contract constant
			Player.currentCompany = companyNames.get(Company2);
			Player.currentOreCount = numberOfOres2;
			Player.currentOre = ores.get(Ore2);
			Player.currentPrice = price2;
			
			//start the main menu
			menu.start();
		
		}
		
		//If they choose the third contract
		if (input.input.equals("3")) {
		
			//set Player boolean to true
			Player.hasContract = true;
			
			//Print out the contract again
			System.out.println("");
			System.out.println("You chose contract 3.");
			System.out.println("");
			System.out.println("From:  " + companyNames.get(Company3));
			System.out.println("Job:   Mine " + numberOfOres3 + " " + ores.get(Ore3));
			System.out.println("Price: " + price3 + " Gold Coins");
			System.out.println("");
			
			//set Player values for keeping the contract constant
			Player.currentCompany = companyNames.get(Company3);
			Player.currentOreCount = numberOfOres3;
			Player.currentOre = ores.get(Ore3);
			Player.currentPrice = price3;
			
			//start the main menu
			menu.start();
		
		}
		
		//If they choose the fourth contract
		if (input.input.equals("4")) {
			
			//set Player boolean to true
			Player.hasContract = true;
			
			//Print out the contract again
			System.out.println("");
			System.out.println("You chose contract 4.");
			System.out.println("");
			System.out.println("From:  " + companyNames.get(Company4));
			System.out.println("Job:   Mine " + numberOfOres4 + " " + ores.get(Ore4));
			System.out.println("Price: " + price4 + " Gold Coins");
			System.out.println("");
			
			//set Player values for keeping the contract constant
			Player.currentCompany = companyNames.get(Company4);
			Player.currentOreCount = numberOfOres4;
			Player.currentOre = ores.get(Ore4);
			Player.currentPrice = price4;
			
			//start the main menu
			menu.start();
		
		}

	//If the player does have a contract
	} else {
	
		//Print out that the player already has a contract and the contract
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.println("You currently have a contract!");
		System.out.println("");
		System.out.println("From:  " + Player.currentCompany);
		System.out.println("Job:   Mine " + Player.currentOreCount + " " + Player.currentOre);
		System.out.println("Price: " + Player.currentPrice + " Gold Coins");
		System.out.println("");
		
		//start the main menu
		menu.start();
		
	
	
	}

}

}[/code]

Thanks guys!!!

item.title: [Java] Too much code
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

That’s right now. Technically you don’t need the final break;, since it’s at the end anyway, but it’s a good idea to leave it since you might go back and add more later and forget about it!

item.title: [Java] Too much code
item.dc:creator: @JamesM JamesM
item.description:
@JamesM wrote:

Oh damn, I’ve been away from Java and in Pawn for so long I forgot. Sorry! This is the right way:

switch(randomOreCount) { case 1: price = 10; break; case 2: price = 20; break; }

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Too much code
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“JamesM, post:12, topic:383289”]Switch statements are simple:

switch(randomOreCount) { case 1: price = 10; case 2: price = 20; }

And such.[/quote]

That isn’t right, you didn’t put ‘break’ after your case statements so whether randomOreCount is 1 or 2, price will be set to 20. Try it for yourself and see!

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Too much code
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I think separating it into different classes is a bad idea. It wouldn’t shorten or clean up your code, just move it around.

I’ll give you a quick example on how to greatly simplify one if statement, it can be applied to the rest as well:

if (ores.get(Ore1).equals("Stone. ")) { int basePrice = 50; int priceIncrement = 10; price = basePrice + (priceIncrement * randomOreCount); }

That sets the price the same way you do right? Plus it makes it easier and cleaner to understand and change in the future. Implement that for all of those, post it, and I’ll see if I can help you more.

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Too much code
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

sp11k3t3ht3rd:

@LilXCj, The company, and the jobs, and price are completely independent. Non of those values rely on each other and are just randomly chosen. I don’t see the benefit in putting the companies as different classes unless I change it so certain companies have certain jobs. I might just keep it the way it is as of right now, but as I typed that last sentence I started to like the idea of company dependent jobs.

Like I said, separate them into different classes. Whether or not it is “randomly” chosen does not matter. It is still much cleaner programming to do so. You say it is randomly chosen and that much is true. Taking a look at the code again, I don’t see why you keep the ore types together too. It’s not proper programming to make one method and/or class do the work that several classes could do, quicker and without straining the eyes of those who look at the code itself.

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Too much code
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2

Holy hell.

Suggestions - Have a set discount ratio and price for each ore, then just multiply it by the number of ore. (like 1.9 or something)

I don’t see the benefit in putting the companies as different classes unless I change it so certain companies have certain jobs. I might just keep it the way it is as of right now, but as I typed that last sentence I started to like the idea of company dependent jobs.

@`Alec, Considering my current knowledge of Java and various programming terms that description of a hashmap went right over my head.

item.title: [Java] Too much code
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

sp11k3t3ht3rd:

I haven’t learned about switch statements in Java yet. Would that be the only way to shorten it up? Besides removing brackets because it’s my personal preference to keep those.

That or seperating it into two classes. Switch statements are the best way to go when looking at the code.

switch(randomOreCount) { case 0: //if the random number lands on 0 //do stuff break; case 1: //if it lands on 1 ... break; }

Just an example.

You would also find it better if you made the classes like this.

ContractSystem.class
WorldFallout.class
BlackFallout.class
etc.

Let your ContractSystem.class handle all the procedures of “contracting” (I think this is what you’re trying to do) and let your business classes hold the data the contract class needs to get.

Read full topic

item.title: [Java] Too much code
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

Is there anyway to shorten this up? It’s really fucking long.

I didn’t need to use the array lists but I don’t feel like changing it especially considering all the code I would have to change.

[code]import java.util.*;

//ContractSystem Class
public class ContractSystem {

//Make objects out of the necessary classes
mainMenu menu = new mainMenu();
userInput input = new userInput();

//Declare variables
ArrayList<String> companyNames = new ArrayList<String>();
ArrayList<String> ores = new ArrayList<String>();

//addCompanies method
public void addCompanys () {

	//Add company names
	companyNames.add("World Fallout Co. ");
	companyNames.add("Black Fallout Co. ");
	companyNames.add("Break Zombie Co.  ");
	companyNames.add("Stone Zombie Co.  ");
	companyNames.add("Stone Heroes Co.  ");
	companyNames.add("Ghost Method Co.  ");

}

//ores Method
public void ores() {

	//Add ores to the ores array list
	ores.add("Stone.   ");
	ores.add("Coal.    ");
	ores.add("Iron.    ");
	ores.add("Gold.    ");
	ores.add("Diamond. ");

}

//Contract method
public void contracts () {

	//Declare and initialize variables
	int randomCompany = (int) (Math.random() * companyNames.size());
	int randomOreCount = (int) (Math.random() * 9) + 1;
	int randomOre = (int) (Math.random() * ores.size());
	int price = 0;
	int Ore1 = randomOre;
	randomOre = (int) (Math.random() * ores.size());
	int Ore2 = randomOre;
	randomOre = (int) (Math.random() * ores.size());
	int Ore3 = randomOre;
	randomOre = (int) (Math.random() * ores.size());
	int Ore4 = randomOre;
	
	/*
	* This is an explanation to ALL OF the following code rather than have tons and tons of comments.
	* There are 4 if statments checking to see if the random ore chosen equals Stone Coal Iron Gold or Diamond.
	* There are 4 sets of those 4 for each time the ore is printed out in the decription part of the chart
	* Within the if statements there are more if statements to check the number of ores that gets printed out.
	* Depending on the ore the price will always me + 50 Gold Coins from selling that number of ores in the shop.
	* All of the internal if statments are for setting the price.
	* It takes all this information to print out the contract screen showing company names, the job with the ore and number of ores, and the price of the job.
	* I documented this the best I could. Above is everything that happens in the following code.
	*/

This is an example of what that code does:

[code]Welcome to the game!

| Option | Description |
|-------------------------------------|
| mine | Go to the mine |
| shop | Go to the shop |
| save | Save your game |
| load | Load your game |
| contract | Go to the contact system |

Enter your choice:
contract

| Company: | Decription: | Price: |
|-----------------------------------------------------------|
| Stone Heroes Co. | Mine 5 Coal. | 300 Gold Coins |
| Black Fallout Co. | Mine 4 Diamond. | 2050 Gold Coins |
| World Fallout Co. | Mine 2 Diamond. | 1050 Gold Coins |
| Stone Heroes Co. | Mine 3 Coal. | 200 Gold Coins |

What contract will you accept? (1, 2, 3, 4)
[/code]
